abstract.text: The latitude, longitude, and course information reported by the system.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: object contains the geographical location and altitude of a device, along with values indicating the accuracy of those measurements and when they were collected. In iOS, a location object also contains course information — that is, the speed and heading in which the device was moving.
Typically, you don’t create location objects yourself. After you request location updates from your

object, the system uses onboard sensors to gather location data and report that data to your app. Some services also return previously collected location data, which you can use as context to improve your services. You can always retrieve the most recently collected location from the
object. You may create location objects yourself when you want to cache custom location data or calculate the distance between two geographical coordinates.
objects as-is, and don’t subclass them.

abstract.text: Obtain the geographic location and orientation of a device.
The floor of a building on which the user’s device is located.
The latitude, longitude, and course information reported by the system.
The altitude above mean sea level associated with a location, measured in meters.
The geographical coordinate information.
The direction in which the device is traveling, measured in degrees and relative to due north.
The accuracy of the course value, measured in degrees.
Returns the distance (measured in meters) from the current object’s location to the specified location.
The altitude as a height above the World Geodetic System 1984 (WGS84) ellipsoid, measured in meters.
The logical floor of the building in which the user is located.
Returns the distance (measured in meters) from the current object’s location to the specified location.
The radius of uncertainty for the location, measured in meters.
Creates a location object with the specified coordinate, altitude, course, and accuracy information.
Creates a location object with the specified coordinate, altitude, and course information.
Creates a location object with the specified coordinate and altitude information.
Creates a location object with the specified latitude and longitude.
Information about the source that provides the location.
The instantaneous speed of the device, measured in meters per second.
The accuracy of the speed value, measured in meters per second.
The time at which this location was determined.
The validity of the altitude values, and their estimated uncertainty, measured in meters.
The accuracy of a geographical coordinate.
The latitude and longitude associated with a location, specified using the WGS 84 reference frame.
An azimuth that is measured in degrees relative to true north.
The accuracy of a compass heading.
A distance in meters from an existing location.
The object you use to start and stop the delivery of location-related events to your app.
Information about the source that provides a location.
The velocity (measured in meters per second) at which the device is moving.
The accuracy of a speed.
An object that provides device location updates.
Information about the user’s location during a specific period of time.
Convert between a latitude and longitude pair and a more user-friendly description of that location.

abstract.text: The most recently retrieved user location.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The protocol that provides strong type-checking for objects that the CloudKit framework stores on the server.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
A description of a CloudKit record value.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A type whose values can be implicitly or explicitly copied.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
